description:
Quercus berberidifolia, commonly known as the scrub oak or barberry-leaved oak, is a species of small, evergreen oak tree or shrub native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Fagaceae, which includes other oak species.

This species is typically found in chaparral and coastal sage scrub habitats, often growing in dry, rocky, or sandy soils. Quercus berberidifolia is characterized by its small, leathery, spiny-toothed leaves that resemble the foliage of barberry (Berberis) plants, hence the common name.

The plant exhibits a multi-trunked, shrubby growth habit, reaching heights of 1-6 meters (3-20 feet). Its bark is dark gray to black, and the acorns it produces are small, round, and partially enclosed in a scaly cup.

Quercus berberidifolia is adapted to fire-prone environments and can regenerate from its root system after being burned. It is an important component of the diverse ecosystems it inhabits, providing food and shelter for various wildlife species.
